‚ÄúAnd when I raise my hand ‚Äì so ‚Äì you will throw into the room what I give you to throw, and will, at the same time, raise the cry of fire. You quite follow me?‚Äù
‚ÄúEntirely.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is nothing very formidable,‚Äù he said, taking a long cigar-shaped roll from his pocket. ‚ÄúIt is an ordinary plumber‚Äôs smoke-rocket, fitted with a cap at either end to make it self-lighting. Your task is confined to that. When you raise your cry of fire, it will be taken up by quite a number of people. You may then walk to the end of the street, and I will rejoin you in ten minutes. I hope that I have made myself clear?‚Äù
‚ÄúI am to remain neutral, to get near the window, to watch you, and at the signal to throw in this object, then to raise the cry of fire, and to wait you at the corner of the street.‚Äù
‚ÄúPrecisely.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen you may entirely rely on me.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat is excellent. I think, perhaps, it is almost time that I prepare for the new role I have to play.‚Äù
He disappeared into his bedroom and returned in a few minutes in the character of an amiable and simple-minded Nonconformist clergyman. His broad black hat, his baggy trousers, his white tie, his sympathetic smile, and general look of peering and benevolent curiosity were such as Mr. John Hare alone could have equalled. It was not merely that Holmes changed his costume. His expression, his manner, his very soul seemed to vary with every fresh part that he assumed. The stage lost a fine actor, even as science lost an acute reasoner, when he became a specialist in crime.
It was a quarter past six when we left Baker Street, and it still wanted ten minutes to the hour when we found ourselves in Serpentine Avenue. It was already dusk, and the lamps were just being lighted as we paced up and down in front of Briony Lodge, waiting for the coming of its occupant. The house was just such as I had pictured it from Sherlock Holmes‚Äô succinct description, but the locality appeared to be less private than I expected. On the contrary, for a small street in a quiet neighbourhood, it was remarkably animated. There was a group of shabbily dressed men smoking and laughing in a corner, a scissors-grinder with his wheel, two guardsmen who were flirting with a nurse-girl, and several well-dressed young men who were lounging up and down with cigars in their mouths.
‚ÄúYou see,‚Äù remarked Holmes, as we paced to and fro in front of the house, ‚Äúthis marriage rather simplifies matters. The photograph becomes a double-edged weapon now. The chances are that she would be as averse to its being seen by Mr. Godfrey Norton, as our client is to its coming to the eyes of his princess. Now the question is, Where are we to find the photograph?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhere, indeed?‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is most unlikely that she carries it about with her. It is cabinet size. Too large for easy concealment about a woman‚Äôs dress. She knows that the King is capable of having her waylaid and searched. Two attempts of the sort have already been made. We may take it, then, that she does not carry it about with her.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhere, then?‚Äù
‚ÄúHer banker or her lawyer. There is that double possibility. But I am inclined to think neither. Women are naturally secretive, and they like to do their own secreting. Why should she hand it over to anyone else? She could trust her own guardianship, but she could not tell what indirect or political influence might be brought to bear upon a business man. Besides, remember that she had resolved to use it within a few days. It must be where she can lay her hands upon it. It must be in her own house.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut it has twice been burgled.‚Äù
‚ÄúPshaw! They did not know how to look.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut how will you look?‚Äù
‚ÄúI will not look.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat then?‚Äù
‚ÄúI will get her to show me.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut she will refuse.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe will not be able to. But I hear the rumble of wheels. It is her carriage. Now carry out my orders to the letter.‚Äù
As he spoke the gleam of the side-lights of a carriage came round the curve of the avenue. It was a smart little landau which rattled up to the door of Briony Lodge. As it pulled up, one of the loafing men at the corner dashed forward to open the door in the hope of earning a copper, but was elbowed away by another loafer, who had rushed up with the same intention. A fierce quarrel broke out, which was increased by the two guardsmen, who took sides with one of the loungers, and by the scissors-grinder, who was equally hot upon the other side. A blow was struck, and in an instant the lady, who had stepped from her carriage, was the centre of a little knot of flushed and struggling men, who struck savagely at each other with their fists and sticks. Holmes dashed into the crowd to protect the lady; but just as he reached her he gave a cry and dropped to the ground, with the blood running freely down his face. At his fall the guardsmen took to their heels in one direction and the loungers in the other, while a number of better-dressed people, who had watched the scuffle without taking part in it, crowded in to help the lady and to attend to the injured man. Irene Adler, as I will still call her, had hurried up the steps; but she stood at the top with her superb figure outlined against the lights of the hall, looking back into the street.
‚ÄúIs the poor gentleman much hurt?‚Äù she asked.
‚ÄúHe is dead,‚Äù cried several voices.
‚ÄúNo, no, there‚Äôs life in him!‚Äù shouted another. ‚ÄúBut he‚Äôll be gone before you can get him to hospital.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a brave fellow,‚Äù said a woman. ‚ÄúThey would have had the lady‚Äôs purse and watch if it hadn‚Äôt been for him. They were a gang, and a rough one, too. Ah, he‚Äôs breathing now.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe can‚Äôt lie in the street. May we bring him in, marm?‚Äù
‚ÄúSurely. Bring him into the sitting-room. There is a comfortable sofa. This way, please!‚Äù
Slowly and solemnly he was borne into Briony Lodge and laid out in the principal room, while I still observed the proceedings from my post by the window. The lamps had been lit, but the blinds had not been drawn, so that I could see Holmes as he lay upon the couch. I do not know whether he was seized with compunction at that moment for the part he was playing, but I know that I never felt more heartily ashamed of myself in my life than when I saw the beautiful creature against whom I was conspiring, or the grace and kindliness with which she waited upon the injured man. And yet it would be the blackest treachery to Holmes to draw back now from the part which he had intrusted to me. I hardened my heart, and took the smoke-rocket from under my ulster. After all, I thought, we are not injuring her. We are but preventing her from injuring another.
Holmes had sat up upon the couch, and I saw him motion like a man who is in need of air. A maid rushed across and threw open the window. At the same instant I saw him raise his hand and at the signal I tossed my rocket into the room with a cry of ‚ÄúFire!‚Äù The word was no sooner out of my mouth than the whole crowd of spectators, well dressed and ill ‚Äì gentlemen, ostlers, and servant-maids ‚Äì joined in a general shriek of ‚ÄúFire!‚Äù Thick clouds of smoke curled through the room and out at the open window. I caught a glimpse of rushing figures, and a moment later the voice of Holmes from within assuring them that it was a false alarm. Slipping through the shouting crowd I made my way to the corner of the street, and in ten minutes was rejoiced to find my friend‚Äôs arm in mine, and to get away from the scene of uproar. He walked swiftly and in silence for some few minutes until we had turned down one of the quiet streets which lead towards the Edgeware Road.
‚ÄúYou did it very nicely, Doctor,‚Äù he remarked. ‚ÄúNothing could have been better. It is all right.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou have the photograph?‚Äù
‚ÄúI know where it is.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd how did you find out?‚Äù
‚ÄúShe showed me, as I told you she would.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am still in the dark.‚Äù
‚ÄúI do not wish to make a mystery,‚Äù said he, laughing. ‚ÄúThe matter was perfectly simple. You, of course, saw that everyone in the street was an accomplice. They were all engaged for the evening.‚Äù
‚ÄúI guessed as much.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen, when the row broke out, I had a little moist red paint in the palm of my hand. I rushed forward, fell down, clapped my hand to my face, and became a piteous spectacle. It is an old trick.‚Äù
‚ÄúThat also I could fathom.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen they carried me in. She was bound to have me in. What else could she do? And into her sitting-room, which was the very room which I suspected. It lay between that and her bedroom, and I was determined to see which. They laid me on a couch, I motioned for air, they were compelled to open the window, and you had your chance.‚Äù
‚ÄúHow did that help you?‚Äù
‚ÄúIt was all-important. When a woman thinks that her house is on fire, her instinct is at once to rush to the thing which she values most. It is a perfectly overpowering impulse, and I have more than once taken advantage of it. In the case of the Darlington substitution scandal it was of use to me, and also in the Arnsworth Castle business. A married woman grabs at her baby; an unmarried one reaches for her jewel-box. Now it was clear to me that our lady of to-day had nothing in the house more precious to her than what we are in quest of. She would rush to secure it. The alarm of fire was admirably done. The smoke and shouting were enough to shake nerves of steel. She responded beautifully. The photograph is in a recess behind a sliding panel just above the right bell-pull. She was there in an instant, and I caught a glimpse of it as she half-drew it out. When I cried out that it was a false alarm, she replaced it, glanced at the rocket, rushed from the room, and I have not seen her since. I rose, and, making my excuses, escaped from the house. I hesitated whether to attempt to secure the photograph at once; but the coachman had come in, and as he was watching me narrowly it seemed safer to wait. A little over-precipitance may ruin all.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd now?‚Äù I asked.
‚ÄúOur quest is practically finished. I shall call with the King to-morrow, and with you, if you care to come with us. We will be shown into the sitting-room to wait for the lady, but it is probable that when she comes she may find neither us nor the photograph. It might be a satisfaction to his Majesty to regain it with his own hands.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd when will you call?‚Äù
‚ÄúAt eight in the morning. She will not be up, so that we shall have a clear field. Besides, we must be prompt, for this marriage may mean a complete change in her life and habits. I must wire to the King without delay.‚Äù
We had reached Baker Street and had stopped at the door. He was searching his pockets for the key when someone passing said:
‚ÄúGood-night, Mister Sherlock Holmes.‚Äù
There were several people on the pavement at the time, but the greeting appeared to come from a slim youth in an ulster who had hurried by.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard that voice before,‚Äù said Holmes, staring down the dimly lit street. ‚ÄúNow, I wonder who the deuce that could have been.‚Äù
I slept at Baker Street that night, and we were engaged upon our toast and coffee in the morning when the King of Bohemia rushed into the room.
‚ÄúYou have really got it!‚Äù he cried, grasping Sherlock Holmes by either shoulder and looking eagerly into his face.
‚ÄúNot yet.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut you have hopes?‚Äù
‚ÄúI have hopes.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen, come. I am all impatience to be gone.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe must have a cab.‚Äù
‚ÄúNo, my brougham is waiting.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen that will simplify matters.‚Äù We descended and started off once more for Briony Lodge.
‚ÄúIrene Adler is married,‚Äù remarked Holmes.
‚ÄúMarried! When?‚Äù
‚ÄúYesterday.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut to whom?‚Äù
‚ÄúTo an English lawyer named Norton.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut she could not love him.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am in hopes that she does.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd why in hopes?‚Äù
‚ÄúBecause it would spare your Majesty all fear of future annoyance. If the lady loves her husband, she does not love your Majesty. If she does not love your Majesty, there is no reason why she should interfere with your Majesty‚Äôs plan.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is true. And yet ‚Äì Well! I wish she had been of my own station! What a queen she would have made!‚Äù He relapsed into a moody silence, which was not broken until we drew up in Serpentine Avenue.
The door of Briony Lodge was open, and an elderly woman stood upon the steps. She watched us with a sardonic eye as we stepped from the brougham.
‚ÄúMr. Sherlock Holmes, I believe?‚Äù said she.
‚ÄúI am Mr. Holmes,‚Äù answered my companion, looking at her with a questioning and rather startled gaze.
‚ÄúIndeed! My mistress told me that you were likely to call. She left this morning with her husband by the 5:15 train from Charing Cross for the Continent.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat!‚Äù Sherlock Holmes staggered back, white with chagrin and surprise. ‚ÄúDo you mean that she has left England?‚Äù
‚ÄúNever to return.‚Äù
‚ÄúAnd the papers?‚Äù asked the King hoarsely. ‚ÄúAll is lost.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe shall see.‚Äù He pushed past the servant and rushed into the drawing-room, followed by the King and myself. The furniture was scattered about in every direction, with dismantled shelves and open drawers, as if the lady had hurriedly ransacked them before her flight. Holmes rushed at the bell-pull, tore back a small sliding shutter, and, plunging in his hand, pulled out a photograph and a letter. The photograph was of Irene Adler herself in evening dress, the letter was superscribed to ‚ÄúSherlock Holmes, Esq. To be left till called for.‚Äù My friend tore it open and we all three read it together. It was dated at midnight of the preceding night and ran in this way:
‚ÄúWhat a woman ‚Äì oh, what a woman!‚Äù cried the King of Bohemia, when we had all three read this epistle. ‚ÄúDid I not tell you how quick and resolute she was? Would she not have made an admirable queen? Is it not a pity that she was not on my level?‚Äù
‚ÄúFrom what I have seen of the lady she seems indeed to be on a very different level to your Majesty,‚Äù said Holmes coldly. ‚ÄúI am sorry that I have not been able to bring your Majesty‚Äôs business to a more successful conclusion.‚Äù
‚ÄúOn the contrary, my dear sir,‚Äù cried the King; ‚Äúnothing could be more successful. I know that her word is inviolate. The photograph is now as safe as if it were in the fire.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am glad to hear your Majesty say so.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am immensely indebted to you. Pray tell me in what way I can reward you. This ring ‚Äì ‚Äù He slipped an emerald snake ring from his finger and held it out upon the palm of his hand.
‚ÄúYour Majesty has something which I should value even more highly,‚Äù said Holmes.
‚ÄúYou have but to name it.‚Äù
‚ÄúThis photograph!‚Äù
The King stared at him in amazement.
‚ÄúIrene‚Äôs photograph!‚Äù he cried. ‚ÄúCertainly, if you wish it.‚Äù
‚ÄúI thank your Majesty. Then there is no more to be done in the matter. I have the honour to wish you a very good-morning.‚Äù He bowed, and, turning away without observing the hand which the King had stretched out to him, he set off in my company for his chambers.
And that was how a great scandal threatened to affect the kingdom of Bohemia, and how the best plans of Mr. Sherlock Holmes were beaten by a woman‚Äôs wit. He used to make merry over the cleverness of women, but I have not heard him do it of late. And when he speaks of Irene Adler, or when he refers to her photograph, it is always under the honourable title of the woman.

This guy Sherlock Holmes, he always calls her ‚ÄúTHE woman.‚Äù I hardly ever hear him call her by her real name. To him, she‚Äôs the only woman in the world.  It's not like he was in love with Irene Adler or anything.  Nope, Holmes hated feelings and stuff, especially love.  He thought they were dumb. He was all about being a super-smart, logical dude - like a human computer. Love would‚Äôve messed up his whole vibe. To him, feelings were just something he observed in other people so he could figure them out, not something he wanted for himself. Can‚Äôt have your brain all mushy when you‚Äôre solving mysteries, right? But yeah, there was only this one woman for him, and she was Irene Adler. And her reputation? Well, it wasn't exactly squeaky clean.

I hadn't seen much of Holmes recently. Ever since I got married, we‚Äôd drifted apart. I was busy being a happy newlywed and all that, which took up all my time.  Meanwhile, Holmes, who hated parties and anything social, was holed up in our Baker Street apartment. He‚Äôd switch between being totally zonked out on cocaine and then suddenly being obsessed with some case or another - talk about an intense guy. He still loved anything to do with crime and used his crazy-good memory and detective skills to solve mysteries that even the cops had given up on. Every once in a while, I‚Äôd hear about some big case he cracked - like that murder in Russia, or the mystery of those brothers in India, or even helping out the royal family in Holland. But besides what I read in the newspapers, I didn't really know what my old friend was up to.

Then one night - March 20th, 1888 - I was coming home from seeing a patient.  Yeah, I was back to being a regular doctor now. Anyway, my walk took me through Baker Street, and as I passed our old place, which brought back a lot of memories, I suddenly felt this urge to see Holmes again and find out what he was up to.  His windows were blazing with light, and as I looked up, I saw his tall, skinny shadow moving back and forth.  He was pacing like crazy, his head down, hands behind his back.  I knew him like the back of my hand, and this meant only one thing: he was on a case.  He‚Äôd shaken off whatever druggy haze he was in and was hot on the trail of something new. I rang the bell.

He wasn't exactly what you'd call warm and fuzzy when he opened the door, but I could tell he was happy to see me.  He just waved me into our old room without saying much. He pointed to his cigars and drinks, then stood by the fireplace, just studying me with those intense eyes.

‚ÄúMarriage looks good on you,‚Äù he said, out of nowhere. "I‚Äôd say you‚Äôve put on about seven and a half pounds since I last saw you."

‚ÄúSeven?‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYeah, actually, maybe a bit more. Just a tad, I‚Äôd say. And you‚Äôre back at work, I see.  You didn't tell me you were going back to being a doctor."

‚ÄúHow did you know?‚Äù

‚ÄúFigured it out. It‚Äôs obvious. Like, it‚Äôs pretty clear you've been caught in the rain lately and that you have a totally useless maid.‚Äù

‚ÄúHolmes, how on earth‚Ä¶?‚Äù I started, but he cut me off.

He chuckled and rubbed his hands together like he was about to tell a joke.

"Elementary, my dear Watson! My eyes tell me that on your left shoe, right where the firelight hits it, the leather has six little cuts on it, all almost perfectly parallel. Obviously, someone scraped the mud off your shoes, but did a terrible job. Hence, my friend, you were out in awful weather and you have a maid who should be fired immediately. I couldn't help but laugh; he made it seem so easy! ‚ÄúWhen you explain it," I said, "it's always so simple. I feel like I could do it too, but then you hit me with another one of your deductions, and I'm clueless again.  My eyes are as good as yours, though!‚Äù

‚ÄúSure they are," he said, lighting a cigarette and slumping into a chair.  ‚ÄúThe thing is, you see, but you don‚Äôt observe.  Big difference.  For example, you've seen the steps up to this room how many times?‚Äù

"A lot!"

"How many, exactly?"

"I don't know, hundreds?"

"Exactly! You haven‚Äôt observed. But you‚Äôve seen them. That‚Äôs my whole point. Now me, I‚Äôve both seen and observed, so I know there are seventeen steps. Speaking of little mysteries, since you like that sort of thing and you're writing down all our adventures, this might interest you.‚Äù He threw a pink piece of paper at me.  "Came in the mail just now,‚Äù he said.  ‚ÄúRead it out loud."

The note didn't have a date, name, or anything. 

‚ÄúA gentleman will call on you tonight at a quarter to eight,‚Äù it read. ‚ÄúHe needs your advice on something extremely important.  People say you can be trusted with top-secret info, what with you helping out those European royals and all. Be in your room, and don‚Äôt freak out if he‚Äôs wearing a mask.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow that is weird," I said.  ‚ÄúWhat do you think it all means?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have enough info yet,‚Äù he said.  ‚ÄúBiggest mistake is to start making theories before you have all the facts. You‚Äôll end up twisting the facts to fit your theory instead of the other way around.  Let‚Äôs look at the note itself. What do you make of it?‚Äù

I studied the note and paper carefully.

‚ÄúWell, looks like our mystery man‚Äôs loaded,‚Äù I said, trying to think like Holmes. ‚ÄúThis paper is fancy, wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if it cost a pretty penny. It‚Äôs thick and stiff, too.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeculiar, that‚Äôs the right word," Holmes said.  ‚ÄúNot even English paper. Hold it up to the light.‚Äù

I did, and saw a big ‚ÄúE‚Äù with a little ‚Äúg‚Äù, then a ‚ÄúP‚Äù, then a big ‚ÄúG‚Äù with a little ‚Äút‚Äù all woven into the paper.

‚ÄúWell?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúProbably the paper company‚Äôs name. Or maybe a logo?‚Äù

‚ÄúNope. The ‚ÄúG‚Äù with the little ‚Äút‚Äù means ‚ÄòGesellschaft,‚Äô which is German for ‚ÄòCompany.‚Äô  Like we shorten it to ‚ÄòCo.‚Äô  ‚ÄúP‚Äù is for ‚ÄòPapier‚Äô - paper, obviously.  Now, for the ‚ÄúEg‚Äù.  Time to consult my trusty Continental Gazetteer!‚Äù  He grabbed a huge book from his shelf.  "Eglof, Eglonitz‚Ä¶. Ah, here we are: Egria.  It's in Bohemia, where they speak German. Not far from Carlsbad.  Listen to this: ‚ÄòFamous for being where that Wallenstein guy died and also for its glass factories and paper mills.‚Äô  Ha!  Get it?‚Äù  He was practically bouncing in his chair, his eyes bright with excitement, a cloud of smoke puffing from his cigarette.

‚ÄúThe paper was made in Bohemia,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúExactly! Which means our mystery note writer is German. Did you notice how the sentence is structured? ‚ÄòThis account of you we have from all quarters received.‚Äô No Frenchman or Russian would write it like that.  Germans and their verbs, right?  So now we just have to find out what this masked German who uses Bohemian paper wants. And speak of the devil, here he comes now, I do believe.‚Äù

Just then, a carriage screeched to a stop outside.

‚ÄúTwo horses by the sound of it,‚Äù Holmes said. "Yup, a fancy little carriage and two beautiful horses. Worth a fortune.  This case is interesting already, Watson."

"Maybe I should go, Holmes," I said.

‚ÄúNonsense, stay put, Doctor! I‚Äôm lost without my trusty sidekick. Besides, I have a feeling this is gonna be good.  Be a shame to miss it.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut what about your client?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you worry about him, I may need your help and so might he. Ah, here he is. You just sit tight and listen closely.‚Äù

We heard heavy footsteps coming up the stairs and then a loud, commanding knock.

‚ÄúCome in!‚Äù shouted Holmes.

The guy who walked in was huge, at least six foot six, built like a tank.  He was dressed super expensively, but in a way that would be considered pretty tacky in England. His coat was trimmed with fur, and he had this huge emerald brooch holding his cloak closed. He took off his hat as he came in, but the top half of his face was covered with a black mask. He looked like he‚Äôd just put it on because his hand was still on it.  You could tell he was a strong-willed guy just from the lower half of his face; he had this thick, frowning mouth and a stubborn-looking chin. 

‚ÄúYou got my note?‚Äù he asked. His voice was deep and rough, and he had a thick German accent. "I said I‚Äôd come." He glanced back and forth between me and Holmes.

"Have a seat,‚Äù said Holmes. ‚ÄúThis is my friend, Dr. Watson, he helps me out with cases sometimes. Who should I say is calling?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can call me Count Von Kramm,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúA Bohemian nobleman.  This gentleman, your friend, I assume he‚Äôs trustworthy and can keep a secret? This is a matter of utmost importance. Otherwise, I prefer to speak with you alone."

I started to get up, but Holmes grabbed my wrist and pulled me back down. ‚ÄúEither he stays,‚Äù Holmes said, ‚Äúor you‚Äôre talking to an empty room. What you say to me, you can say in front of him."

The Count shrugged.  ‚ÄúVery well,‚Äù he said.  ‚ÄúFirst, I need your word that you will both keep this absolutely secret for two years. After that, it won‚Äôt matter. But right now, let‚Äôs just say it‚Äôs a big deal. Could even change European history, important stuff.‚Äù

‚ÄúI promise,‚Äù said Holmes.

‚ÄúMe too,‚Äù I said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll excuse the mask,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúThe person I work for, he wants to remain anonymous.  Truth be told, ‚ÄúCount‚Äù isn‚Äôt exactly my real title either."

‚ÄúI knew that already,‚Äù Holmes said casually.

‚ÄúThis is a delicate situation," the Count said. "We need to be careful to prevent a massive scandal that could seriously damage one of the most important families in Europe. To put it bluntly, this involves the House of Ormstein, the royal family of Bohemia."

‚ÄúYeah, figured that out too,‚Äù mumbled Holmes, getting comfortable in his chair and closing his eyes like he was bored.

Our visitor seemed surprised. He was probably expecting the most brilliant detective in the world to be a bit more‚Ä¶ alert. Holmes opened his eyes slowly and looked impatiently at his client.

‚ÄúIf you would be so kind as to tell me what‚Äôs going on,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúthen perhaps I could help you."

The guy jumped up and started pacing, really agitated. Finally, he ripped the mask off his face and chucked it on the floor.  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right!‚Äù he shouted,  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the King! No point hiding it!"

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre telling me,‚Äù Holmes said under his breath. ‚ÄúI knew I was talking to Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond von Ormstein, Grand Duke of Cassel-Felstein, and King of Bohemia before you even said a word."

‚ÄúOf course, of course,‚Äù said the King, sitting back down and wiping his brow.  "But I don‚Äôt usually do business like this, you know? But this situation, it's just so sensitive. I couldn‚Äôt trust anyone else to handle it.  I had to come to London in disguise just to talk to you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell then, by all means, let‚Äôs talk,‚Äù said Holmes, closing his eyes again.

‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the deal: about five years ago, I was in Warsaw for a while and I met this woman, quite the character, name of Irene Adler. You‚Äôve heard of her?‚Äù

‚ÄúLook her up in my files, would you, Watson?‚Äù Holmes said, not even bothering to open his eyes.  He kept these meticulous records on everyone and everything; it was amazing. I found her file wedged between a rabbi and a naval officer who'd written about fish.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see‚Ä¶,‚Äù said Holmes. ‚ÄúHmm, born in New Jersey, 1858.  Contralto‚Ä¶ interesting.  Sang at La Scala‚Ä¶ impressive.  Lead singer at the Imperial Opera in Warsaw, no less.  Retired from singing, huh?  Living in London now, is she?  Let me guess, Your Majesty, you had a little fling with this woman, wrote some letters you probably shouldn‚Äôt have, and now you want them back?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right!  But how did you‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúTell me, was there a secret marriage?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

‚ÄúAny legal documents? A marriage certificate?‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing at all.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen I‚Äôm not sure I understand the problem, Your Majesty.  If this woman tries to blackmail you with these letters, how can she prove they‚Äôre real?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe handwriting.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlease, that‚Äôs easy to fake.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was on my personal stationery."

‚ÄúCould‚Äôve been stolen.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt has my seal on it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeone could‚Äôve copied it.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy photo‚Äôs in it!‚Äù

‚ÄúCould‚Äôve bought that.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre both in the photo!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh dear, that‚Äôs not good. You really messed up this time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was a fool!  Out of my mind!"

‚ÄúThis is serious. You‚Äôve compromised yourself.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was just the Crown Prince back then, I was young and stupid! I‚Äôm only thirty now!‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have to get that photo back.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve tried everything, nothing worked.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll have to pay her. Buy it back."

‚ÄúShe won‚Äôt sell.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen we‚Äôll have to steal it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe tried that five times already! My guys broke into her house twice. Once we stole her luggage when she was traveling. And she was ambushed twice. Nothing!‚Äù

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt find a single clue?‚Äù

‚ÄúNothing.‚Äù

Holmes chuckled. ‚ÄúThis is quite a little problem, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a huge problem for me,‚Äù the King said.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right, it is. So what‚Äôs she going to do with this photo?‚Äù

‚ÄúRuin me.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut how?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm about to get married.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I‚Äôve heard.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo Clotilde Lothman von Saxe-Meiningen, the Scandinavian King‚Äôs second daughter. You must know her family is very strict.  And she‚Äôs the picture of innocence.  Even the tiniest whiff of scandal would end things instantly.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd Irene Adler?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs going to send them that photo, I know she will.  You don‚Äôt know her, she‚Äôs got a will of iron. Most beautiful woman you‚Äôve ever seen, but with the mind of a ruthless criminal. She‚Äôll do anything to stop me from marrying this other woman, anything.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre certain she hasn‚Äôt sent the photo yet?‚Äù

‚ÄúPositive.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy are you so sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause she told me she would send it the day the engagement is announced.  This Monday.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, good thing we have three days then,‚Äù Holmes said, yawning.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a couple of loose ends to tie up at the moment. Your Majesty will be staying in London for the time being, I presume?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course, of course.  You can reach me at the Langham Hotel, under the name Count Von Kramm."

‚ÄúI‚Äôll let you know how things are going."

‚ÄúPlease do, I‚Äôm on pins and needles over here."

‚ÄúNow, about payment‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry about it, the sky‚Äôs the limit."

‚ÄúSeriously?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd give you one of my provinces for that photo, I‚Äôm not kidding."

‚ÄúAnd for expenses?‚Äù

The King took out a fat leather bag and tossed it on the table. ‚ÄúThree hundred in gold, seven hundred in cash,‚Äù he said.

Holmes scribbled him a receipt.  ‚ÄúAnd the lady‚Äôs address?‚Äù

‚ÄúBriony Lodge, on Serpentine Avenue in St. John‚Äôs Wood."

Holmes wrote it down.  ‚ÄúJust one more thing: was the photo a cabinet card?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, it was.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight then, good night, Your Majesty. I think we‚Äôll have good news for you soon. And good night to you too, Watson,‚Äù he said as we heard the royal carriage pulling away.  ‚ÄúCome by tomorrow afternoon around three, we‚Äôll talk about this whole thing.‚Äù

At three o‚Äôclock sharp, I was back on Baker Street. No sign of Holmes.  His landlady said he‚Äôd left early that morning. So I sat by the fire, waiting. I have to admit, this case had really piqued my interest. Even though it wasn‚Äôt a murder or anything, something about the mystery of the missing photo, and who this Irene Adler really was, not to mention having a king as a client, made it all very intriguing. Plus, it was fascinating to watch Holmes work; he was so incredibly sharp and observant.  I was so used to him being right that I never even considered the possibility of him failing.

It was almost four when he finally showed up, looking like he‚Äôd been on a bender! He had on these shabby clothes, his face was red and kind of swollen, and he had these ridiculous sideburns. I knew Holmes was a master of disguise, but I swear, I had to look three times before I was sure it was really him!  He gave me a quick nod and disappeared into his bedroom.  Five minutes later, he came out, back to his normal self, wearing his usual tweed suit. He shoved his hands in his pockets, stretched out his legs in front of the fire, and burst out laughing.

‚ÄúYou are not going to believe this!‚Äù he said, but then he started choking and laughing so hard he could barely breathe.  

‚ÄúWhat? What is it?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just‚Ä¶ too perfect.  You‚Äôll never guess what I‚Äôve been up to all day!‚Äù 

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt even imagine. I‚Äôm assuming you went to check out Miss Adler‚Äôs place and see what she's like?"

‚ÄúBingo.  But you won‚Äôt believe what happened!  I left here around eight this morning, dressed as a groom who was out of work.  Guys who like horses always stick together, did you know that? Easy to blend in, and you learn all sorts of things.  Found Briony Lodge easy enough. Small, but nice, with a garden in the back, right on the street. Two floors.  Basic lock on the door.  Big living room on the right with those huge windows - easy to open, even a kid could do it.  Nothing much in the back, except that you could reach the passage window from the roof of the coach house.  I walked around the whole place, checked it out good, but didn't see anything else important.

"So I headed down to the end of the street where I figured there‚Äôd be stables, and I was right. I helped the stable boys groom the horses and got a couple pennies, some watered-down beer, a few cigarettes, and more information than I could ever want about our Miss Adler -  not to mention all the gossip about half the neighborhood!  Not that I cared about them, but I had to pretend to be interested."

‚ÄúAnd what about Irene Adler? What did you learn?‚Äù 

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs just say all the guys were head over heels for her, she's quite a looker, apparently.  The prettiest woman any of them had ever seen. That's what they all said at the stables, anyway. Quiet life: sings at concerts, goes for a drive at five, home for dinner at seven sharp. Doesn‚Äôt go out much other than for her concerts. Has this one guy who visits her a lot - a good-looking fella with dark hair. Comes at least once a day, sometimes twice.  Name‚Äôs Godfrey Norton, lawyer. See, being a cabby, you learn all sorts of juicy gossip. They‚Äôd driven him home often enough to know everything about him.  So after getting all the dirt, I strolled past Briony Lodge again, planning my next move.

‚ÄúThis Godfrey Norton guy, he‚Äôs a big part of this, I can tell.  Lawyer, that‚Äôs never good. Had to figure out what their deal was. Is she his client?  Friend?  Or something more?  Client, maybe she gave him the photo.  If they were involved, less likely. That was the question, and the answer would determine if I should focus on her place or his. Tricky situation.  Sorry to bore you with all this, but if you‚Äôre going to write all this down, I have to give you the details, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôm following,‚Äù I told him.

He continued, ‚ÄúI was still trying to figure out what to do when a cab pulled up, and this guy jumped out.  He fit the description perfectly: handsome, dark, mustache.  Clearly the Norton fellow. And in a hurry, too. Yelled at the cabby to wait, practically pushed past the maid.  

"He was inside maybe half an hour, pacing back and forth, talking with his hands, totally worked up.  I couldn‚Äôt get a look at her.  Then he came out, even more flustered than before. Checked his watch and yelled at the cabby, ‚ÄòGet me to Gross & Hankey‚Äôs on Regent Street, then St. Monica‚Äôs Church on Edgeware Road - and make it snappy, twenty minutes! You‚Äôll get an extra shilling!‚Äô

"Off they went, and I was trying to decide if I should follow them, when a fancy little carriage came up.  Coachman looked a mess, but the woman who came rushing out of the house and into the carriage, she was beautiful!  Stunning!

‚ÄúSt. Monica‚Äôs, John!" she called out to the driver. "And there‚Äôs a half-sovereign in it for you if you get me there in twenty minutes!"

‚ÄúWatson, I couldn‚Äôt resist. This was too good!  I was about to chase after them, when an empty cab came by.  The driver didn't look too happy to see me, but I got in before he could say anything. ‚ÄòSt. Monica‚Äôs! And step on it, twenty minutes!  There‚Äôs a reward in it for you!‚Äô  It was a quarter after eleven, and I knew exactly what was about to happen. 

‚ÄúThe cabby got us there fast! I swear, I‚Äôve never gone that fast in my life. But the other two, they were already there!  Their horses were steaming; they must‚Äôve really pushed them.  I paid the cabby and raced inside.  There was no one there except for the lovebirds, a priest, and an empty church.  They were huddled together by the altar, and the priest looked like he was arguing with them. I pretended to be some lost soul who wandered in and walked casually down the aisle.  Suddenly, they all turned and looked at me, and Godfrey Norton came running towards me as fast as he could.

‚ÄúThank God!" he said. "You‚Äôll do. Come on, come on!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat? What‚Äôs going on?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúNo time to explain, man, every second counts! Three minutes, or it won‚Äôt be legal!‚Äù

"Next thing I know, they‚Äôve practically dragged me up to the altar, whispering stuff in my ear, and I‚Äôm repeating it! Vouching for all these things I know nothing about! Turns out, they needed a witness to make it legal, and there I was, at the right place at the right time!  Saved the day! The bride gave me a sovereign; I‚Äôm going to have to get myself a pocket watch to wear it on. What a day!‚Äù  And that‚Äôs when he‚Äôd started laughing so hard. 

‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôs a twist,‚Äù I said.  ‚ÄúWhat happened next?‚Äù

‚ÄúMy carefully laid plans were down the drain, that's what! Looked like they were about to take off, so I had to think fast. But then, at the church door, they took off in different directions: he went back to the Temple, she went home. I heard her say to him, ‚ÄòSee you in the park at five, like always.‚Äô  And that was that.  Time to figure something else out.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd‚Ä¶ what exactly are we going to do?‚Äù

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs eat first, then I‚Äôll explain everything. It‚Äôs almost five now, we need to be ready in two hours. Miss Irene - or Mrs. Norton, I guess - will be home from her drive around seven. We‚Äôll be waiting for her.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd then what?‚Äù

‚ÄúJust leave that part to me. I‚Äôve got it all planned out. There‚Äôs just one thing. You can‚Äôt interfere, no matter what.  You got it?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just supposed to blend in?‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly. You might see some things you don‚Äôt like, but stay out of it. Eventually, they‚Äôll bring me inside the house.  Just wait five minutes, and the living room window will open.  You need to be right there, by that window.‚Äù

‚ÄúGot it.‚Äù

‚ÄúKeep your eyes on me, you‚Äôll be able to see me.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd when I raise my hand like this‚Ä¶ you throw this into the room and yell ‚ÄòFire!‚Äô  Got it?  Don‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs nothing dangerous.‚Äù  He pulled something out of his pocket that looked like a big cigar.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a smoke flare, plumbers use them.  Lights on both ends.  That‚Äôs your job, simple as that.  Once you yell ‚ÄúFire!‚Äù, other people will hear and join in.  Then you head down to the end of the street, and I‚Äôll meet you in ten minutes.  You got all that?‚Äù

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see‚Ä¶ I do nothing, I go to the window, I watch for your signal, I throw that thing inside, yell ‚ÄòFire!‚Äô,  and wait for you at the corner.‚Äù

‚ÄúPerfect. I knew I could count on you."

‚ÄúSo, what exactly is the plan?‚Äù

‚ÄúAll in good time. It‚Äôs almost time for me to get into character anyway.‚Äù

He went back to his room and came back a few minutes later dressed like a really nice, but maybe not too bright, priest.  He had on a big black hat, baggy pants, one of those white ties priests wear, and he had this kind of goofy smile that would make you trust him instantly. It was more than just the clothes; his whole demeanor changed. You‚Äôd think he was a completely different person! What a shame he became a detective. He would‚Äôve been an amazing actor.

It was a quarter past six when we left Baker Street, and about ten to seven when we got to Serpentine Avenue. The sun was setting, streetlights were starting to come on, and we were hanging out in front of Briony Lodge, waiting.  It looked exactly like Holmes described, but there were more people around than I expected.  For a small street, it was pretty lively. A bunch of guys were smoking and laughing on the corner, there was a guy sharpening knives with one of those wheels, a couple of soldiers were flirting with a nanny, and some upper-class guys were strutting around smoking cigars.  

"See,‚Äù said Holmes, ‚Äúthe marriage actually makes things simpler. The photo‚Äôs a problem for both of them now. She doesn‚Äôt want her new hubby to see it any more than our friend wants his fianc√©e to see it.  Question is, where is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúGood question."

‚ÄúNo way she‚Äôs carrying it around with her. It‚Äôs too big.  She knows the King‚Äôs men might try to mug her ‚Äì which they already did twice, remember? So yeah, it‚Äôs not on her.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen where is it?‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe her bank? Or a lawyer‚Äôs office? Those are possibilities, but my gut says no.  Women like their secrets, and they like to keep them close. Why trust someone else?  Plus, she‚Äôs planning on using it soon.  Has to be somewhere she can grab it quickly.  It‚Äôs in her house.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs been robbed twice already."

‚ÄúThose guys were amateurs, they wouldn't know a clue if it hit ‚Äòem in the face.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you do?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to look for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not?  Then how‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll get her to show me, it‚Äôs foolproof."

‚ÄúShe‚Äôll never go for it.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe won‚Äôt have a choice. Wait, I hear wheels.  It‚Äôs her.‚Äù

Just as he said it, we saw the lights of a carriage.  A fancy little thing pulled up. One of the guys from the corner ran up to open the door, hoping for a tip, but one of the other guys shoved him out of the way. They got into a huge yelling match, then the soldiers got involved, and the knife-sharpener jumped in too, waving his tools around.  Punches flew, and suddenly this woman, who‚Äôd gotten out of the carriage, was right in the middle of this brawl! Holmes jumped into the chaos to protect her, but as soon as he reached her, he cried out and fell to the ground, blood all over his face. The soldiers and the other guys disappeared, and a bunch of well-dressed people who‚Äôd been watching the fight suddenly rushed forward to help the woman and check on the ‚Äúinjured‚Äù man. Irene Adler, as I still thought of her, ran up the steps to her front door but turned to look back at the commotion.

‚ÄúIs the poor man badly hurt?‚Äù she asked.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs dead!‚Äù shouted some. 

‚ÄúNo, he‚Äôs alive!‚Äù shouted others. ‚ÄúBut he won‚Äôt make it to the hospital in time."

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a brave man,‚Äù said one woman.  ‚ÄúThose thugs were after her purse and her jewels! They‚Äôd have gotten away with it if he hadn't stepped in.  Oh look, he‚Äôs breathing again!"

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt just leave him here in the street!  Can we bring him inside, miss?‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course, of course!  Bring him into the sitting room, there‚Äôs a comfortable sofa in there. This way, quickly!‚Äù

They carefully carried him into the house.  I was watching from my post by the window. They‚Äôd turned on the lights inside, but the curtains weren‚Äôt drawn.  I could see them laying Holmes down on the sofa. Part of me thought he looked guilty about tricking everyone, but honestly, I was the one who felt bad.  Here was this elegant, kind woman, and we were setting her up! But it would be betraying Holmes to back out now.  So I told myself, we‚Äôre not really hurting her, we‚Äôre just stopping her from hurting someone else.

Holmes sat up, pretending like he couldn‚Äôt breathe.  A maid rushed over and opened the window wide.  That was it, that was my cue.  I saw Holmes raise his hand, and I chucked that smoke bomb into the room, yelling "Fire!‚Äù  As soon as the words left my mouth, everyone started shouting ‚ÄúFire! Fire!‚Äù  There was smoke everywhere, pouring out of the window.  I saw people running around, then I heard Holmes yelling that it was a false alarm.  I pushed through the crowd to the corner of the street and ten minutes later, there was Holmes! We hightailed it out of there.  We didn‚Äôt talk until we were a few blocks away, heading toward Edgeware Road.

‚ÄúYou were great, Watson,‚Äù he said.  ‚ÄúCouldn‚Äôt have gone better. Got it.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou got the photo?‚Äù

‚ÄúI know where it is.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt keep me in suspense, how did you find it?‚Äù

‚ÄúShe showed me!  Just like I said she would.‚Äù

‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt understand.‚Äù

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to say anything before," Holmes said, laughing, "but it was all so easy! All those people, they were in on it. Hired for the night.‚Äù

‚ÄúI had a hunch."

‚ÄúSo when that fight broke out, I had some red paint in my hand. Simple trick: I ‚Äòtripped,‚Äô fell down, ‚Äòhurt‚Äô my face, and voila!  Instant victim! Classic move."

‚ÄúOkay, I get that part."

‚ÄúThey had to bring me inside, she didn't have a choice! And where‚Äôd they take me? The sitting room, just like I thought. It was either that room or her bedroom, and I had to see which one. They laid me on the couch, I pretended to faint, they opened the window for air ‚Äì bingo! Opportunity knocked, eh Watson?‚Äù

‚ÄúBut how did that help you?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was everything!  You see, when a woman thinks her house is on fire, she instinctively grabs whatever she cares about most.  It's like a reflex, people panic, and I‚Äôve used that to my advantage more than once. Helped me crack the Darlington case and that whole mess at Arnsworth Castle, too. Married women grab their babies, single women grab their jewelry.  I knew this woman, she doesn‚Äôt care about jewels as much as that photo. She‚Äôd go straight for it. And the fire? Perfect! Smoke, shouting, enough to rattle anyone.  She reacted perfectly. The photo‚Äôs hidden behind a panel above the right bell pull. She went straight there when I yelled ‚ÄòFire!‚Äô and I saw it!  Just a glimpse, as she was putting it back.  Then I said it was a false alarm, she gave me this look, saw the smoke bomb, and ran out. Haven't seen her since.  I got up, said I was fine, and got out. I thought about grabbing the photo then and there, but the coachman was watching me, so I figured it was safer to wait.  Gotta be careful not to rush things."

‚ÄúWhat now?‚Äù I asked. 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs practically done!  I‚Äôll go back tomorrow with the King, and you can come too if you want. We‚Äôll hang out in the sitting room, wait for her to come back ‚Äì although she won‚Äôt find us, or the photo, when she does.  I‚Äôm sure His Majesty would like to get it back personally."

‚ÄúWhat time?‚Äù

‚ÄúEight in the morning.  She won‚Äôt be up by then. Plus, we need to do this before she gets any ideas about changing her routine now that she‚Äôs married. I have to send a telegram to the King.‚Äù

We‚Äôd gotten back to Baker Street.  As Holmes was looking for his key, someone walked by and said, ‚ÄúEvening, Mr. Sherlock Holmes.‚Äù

There were a few other people on the street, but the voice came from a young guy in a long coat who hurried past us. 

‚ÄúI know that voice‚Ä¶" muttered Holmes, peering down the dark street.  ‚ÄúNow who in the world was that?‚Äù

I crashed at his place that night, and the next morning, we were having breakfast when the King of Bohemia came barging in, a wild look in his eyes. 

‚ÄúYou got it!  Tell me you got it!‚Äù he said, grabbing Holmes and shaking him. 

‚ÄúNot yet,‚Äù Holmes said.

‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre hopeful?‚Äù

‚ÄúHopeful.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen let‚Äôs go!  I can‚Äôt wait any longer!" 

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll need to get a cab.‚Äù

‚ÄúMine‚Äôs waiting. Come on!"

We headed down to Briony Lodge.  "Irene Adler got married yesterday,‚Äù Holmes said casually.

‚ÄúWhat? Married? Yesterday?‚Äù

‚ÄúYep.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo who?‚Äù

‚ÄúEnglish lawyer, fellow by the name of Godfrey Norton.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut she couldn't possibly love him.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, I hope she does."

‚ÄúWhy on earth would you hope that?‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause if she loves her husband, she doesn‚Äôt love you. And if she doesn‚Äôt love you, you‚Äôve got nothing to worry about. No reason for her to ruin your marriage."

scenes.scene_summary: The narrator introduces Sherlock Holmes' perspective on Irene Adler, whom Holmes refers to as 'THE woman.' The narrator explains that Holmes was not in love with her but respected her intellect, viewing her as a challenge to his detective skills.
scenes.text_segment: This guy Sherlock Holmes, he always calls her "THE woman." I hardly ever hear him call her by her real name. To him, she's the only woman in the world. It's not like he was in love with Irene Adler or anything. Nope, Holmes hated feelings and stuff, especially love. He thought they were dumb. He was all about being a super-smart, logical dude - like a human computer. Love would've messed up his whole vibe. To him, feelings were just something he observed in other people so he could figure them out, not something he wanted for himself. Can't have your brain all mushy when you're solving mysteries, right? But yeah, there was only this one woman for him, and she was Irene Adler. And her reputation? Well, it wasn't exactly squeaky clean.

scenes.scene_summary: The narrator describes his recent estrangement from Holmes due to his marriage and Holmes' reclusive behavior. He mentions Holmes' drug use and his continued success in solving difficult cases.
scenes.text_segment: I hadn't seen much of Holmes recently. Ever since I got married, we'd drifted apart. I was busy being a happy newlywed and all that, which took up all my time. Meanwhile, Holmes, who hated parties and anything social, was holed up in our Baker Street apartment. He'd switch between being totally zonked out on cocaine and then suddenly being obsessed with some case or another - talk about an intense guy. He still loved anything to do with crime and used his crazy-good memory and detective skills to solve mysteries that even the cops had given up on. Every once in a while, I'd hear about some big case he cracked - like that murder in Russia, or the mystery of those brothers in India, or even helping out the royal family in Holland. But besides what I read in the newspapers, I didn't really know what my old friend was up to.

scenes.scene_summary: On March 20th, 1888, the narrator visits Holmes at Baker Street. He observes Holmes pacing in his room, indicating he's working on a new case. Holmes greets him and demonstrates his deductive skills by analyzing the narrator's appearance.
scenes.text_segment: Then one night - March 20th, 1888 - I was coming home from seeing a patient. Yeah, I was back to being a regular doctor now. Anyway, my walk took me through Baker Street, and as I passed our old place, which brought back a lot of memories, I suddenly felt this urge to see Holmes again and find out what he was up to. His windows were blazing with light, and as I looked up, I saw his tall, skinny shadow moving back and forth. He was pacing like crazy, his head down, hands behind his back. I knew him like the back of my hand, and this meant only one thing: he was on a case. He'd shaken off whatever druggy haze he was in and was hot on the trail of something new. I rang the bell. He wasn't exactly what you'd call warm and fuzzy when he opened the door, but I could tell he was happy to see me. He just waved me into our old room without saying much. He pointed to his cigars and drinks, then stood by the fireplace, just studying me with those intense eyes. "Marriage looks good on you," he said, out of nowhere. "I'd say you've put on about seven and a half pounds since I last saw you." "Seven?" I said. "Yeah, actually, maybe a bit more. Just a tad, I'd say. And you're back at work, I see. You didn't tell me you were going back to being a doctor." "How did you know?" "Figured it out. It's obvious. Like, it's pretty clear you've been caught in the rain lately and that you have a totally useless maid." "Holmes, how on earth‚Ä¶?" I started, but he cut me off. He chuckled and rubbed his hands together like he was about to tell a joke. "Elementary, my dear Watson! My eyes tell me that on your left shoe, right where the firelight hits it, the leather has six little cuts on it, all almost perfectly parallel. Obviously, someone scraped the mud off your shoes, but did a terrible job. Hence, my friend, you were out in awful weather and you have a maid who should be fired immediately. As for your work, let's just say that when a guy comes in here reeking of medical stuff, has a black stain on his finger, and a lump in his coat pocket shaped exactly like a stethoscope, well, I'd have to be blind not to realize he's a doctor." I couldn't help but laugh; he made it seem so easy! "When you explain it," I said, "it's always so simple. I feel like I could do it too, but then you hit me with another one of your deductions, and I'm clueless again. My eyes are as good as yours, though!" "Sure they are," he said, lighting a cigarette and slumping into a chair. "The thing is, you see, but you don't observe. Big difference. For example, you've seen the steps up to this room how many times?" "A lot!" "How many, exactly?" "I don't know, hundreds?" "Exactly! You haven't observed. But you've seen them. That's my whole point. Now me, I've both seen and observed, so I know there are seventeen steps. Speaking of little mysteries, since you like that sort of thing and you're writing down all our adventures, this might interest you." He threw a pink piece of paper at me. "Came in the mail just now," he said. "Read it out loud."

scenes.scene_summary: Holmes receives a mysterious note about a masked gentleman who will visit him. They discuss the note and deduce that it's from a German client using Bohemian paper. As they talk, a carriage arrives outside.
scenes.text_segment: The note didn't have a date, name, or anything. "A gentleman will call on you tonight at a quarter to eight," it read. "He needs your advice on something extremely important. People say you can be trusted with top-secret info, what with you helping out those European royals and all. Be in your room, and don't freak out if he's wearing a mask." "Now that is weird," I said. "What do you think it all means?" "I don't have enough info yet," he said. "Biggest mistake is to start making theories before you have all the facts. You'll end up twisting the facts to fit your theory instead of the other way around. Let's look at the note itself. What do you make of it?" I studied the note and paper carefully. "Well, looks like our mystery man's loaded," I said, trying to think like Holmes. "This paper is fancy, wouldn't be surprised if it cost a pretty penny. It's thick and stiff, too." "Peculiar, that's the right word," Holmes said. "Not even English paper. Hold it up to the light." I did, and saw a big "E" with a little "g", then a "P", then a big "G" with a little "t" all woven into the paper. "Well?" he asked. "Probably the paper company's name. Or maybe a logo?" "Nope. The "G" with the little "t" means 'Gesellschaft,' which is German for 'Company.' Like we shorten it to 'Co.' "P" is for 'Papier' - paper, obviously. Now, for the "Eg". Time to consult my trusty Continental Gazetteer!" He grabbed a huge book from his shelf. "Eglof, Eglonitz‚Ä¶. Ah, here we are: Egria. It's in Bohemia, where they speak German. Not far from Carlsbad. Listen to this: 'Famous for being where that Wallenstein guy died and also for its glass factories and paper mills.' Ha! Get it?" He was practically bouncing in his chair, his eyes bright with excitement, a cloud of smoke puffing from his cigarette. "The paper was made in Bohemia," I said. "Exactly! Which means our mystery note writer is German. Did you notice how the sentence is structured? 'This account of you we have from all quarters received.' No Frenchman or Russian would write it like that. Germans and their verbs, right? So now we just have to find out what this masked German who uses Bohemian paper wants. And speak of the devil, here he comes now, I do believe." Just then, a carriage screeched to a stop outside. "Two horses by the sound of it," Holmes said. "Yup, a fancy little carriage and two beautiful horses. Worth a fortune. This case is interesting already, Watson."

scenes.scene_summary: A masked man, who claims to be Count Von Kramm, arrives at Baker Street. He reveals himself to be the King of Bohemia and explains his problem involving a compromising photograph with Irene Adler.
scenes.text_segment: "Maybe I should go, Holmes," I said. "Nonsense, stay put, Doctor! I'm lost without my trusty sidekick. Besides, I have a feeling this is gonna be good. Be a shame to miss it." "But what about your client?" "Don't you worry about him, I may need your help and so might he. Ah, here he is. You just sit tight and listen closely." We heard heavy footsteps coming up the stairs and then a loud, commanding knock. "Come in!" shouted Holmes. The guy who walked in was huge, at least six foot six, built like a tank. He was dressed super expensively, but in a way that would be considered pretty tacky in England. His coat was trimmed with fur, and he had this huge emerald brooch holding his cloak closed. He took off his hat as he came in, but the top half of his face was covered with a black mask. He looked like he'd just put it on because his hand was still on it. You could tell he was a strong-willed guy just from the lower half of his face; he had this thick, frowning mouth and a stubborn-looking chin. "You got my note?" he asked. His voice was deep and rough, and he had a thick German accent. "I said I'd come." He glanced back and forth between me and Holmes. "Have a seat," said Holmes. "This is my friend, Dr. Watson, he helps me out with cases sometimes. Who should I say is calling?" "You can call me Count Von Kramm," he said. "A Bohemian nobleman. This gentleman, your friend, I assume he's trustworthy and can keep a secret? This is a matter of utmost importance. Otherwise, I prefer to speak with you alone." I started to get up, but Holmes grabbed my wrist and pulled me back down. "Either he stays," Holmes said, "or you're talking to an empty room. What you say to me, you can say in front of him." The Count shrugged. "Very well," he said. "First, I need your word that you will both keep this absolutely secret for two years. After that, it won't matter. But right now, let's just say it's a big deal. Could even change European history, important stuff." "I promise," said Holmes. "Me too," I said. "You'll excuse the mask," he continued. "The person I work for, he wants to remain anonymous. Truth be told, "Count" isn't exactly my real title either." "I knew that already," Holmes said casually. "This is a delicate situation," the Count said. "We need to be careful to prevent a massive scandal that could seriously damage one of the most important families in Europe. To put it bluntly, this involves the House of Ormstein, the royal family of Bohemia." "Yeah, figured that out too," mumbled Holmes, getting comfortable in his chair and closing his eyes like he was bored. Our visitor seemed surprised. He was probably expecting the most brilliant detective in the world to be a bit more‚Ä¶ alert. Holmes opened his eyes slowly and looked impatiently at his client. "If you would be so kind as to tell me what's going on," he said, "then perhaps I could help you." The guy jumped up and started pacing, really agitated. Finally, he ripped the mask off his face and chucked it on the floor. "You're right!" he shouted, "I'm the King! No point hiding it!" "You're telling me," Holmes said under his breath. "I knew I was talking to Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond von Ormstein, Grand Duke of Cassel-Felstein, and King of Bohemia before you even said a word." "Of course, of course," said the King, sitting back down and wiping his brow. "But I don't usually do business like this, you know? But this situation, it's just so sensitive. I couldn't trust anyone else to handle it. I had to come to London in disguise just to talk to you." "Well then, by all means, let's talk," said Holmes, closing his eyes again. "Here's the deal: about five years ago, I was in Warsaw for a while and I met this woman, quite the character, name of Irene Adler. You've heard of her?" "Look her up in my files, would you, Watson?" Holmes said, not even bothering to open his eyes. He kept these meticulous records on everyone and everything; it was amazing. I found her file wedged between a rabbi and a naval officer who'd written about fish. "Let's see‚Ä¶," said Holmes. "Hmm, born in New Jersey, 1858. Contralto‚Ä¶ interesting. Sang at La Scala‚Ä¶ impressive. Lead singer at the Imperial Opera in Warsaw, no less. Retired from singing, huh? Living in London now, is she? Let me guess, Your Majesty, you had a little fling with this woman, wrote some letters you probably shouldn't have, and now you want them back?" "That's right! But how did you‚Ä¶?" "Tell me, was there a secret marriage?" "No." "Any legal documents? A marriage certificate?" "Nothing at all." "Then I'm not sure I understand the problem, Your Majesty. If this woman tries to blackmail you with these letters, how can she prove they're real?" "The handwriting." "Please, that's easy to fake." "It was on my personal stationery." "Could've been stolen." "It has my seal on it." "Someone could've copied it." "My photo's in it!" "Could've bought that." "We're both in the photo!" "Oh dear, that's not good. You really messed up this time." "I was a fool! Out of my mind!" "This is serious. You've compromised yourself." "I was just the Crown Prince back then, I was young and stupid! I'm only thirty now!" "We have to get that photo back." "We've tried everything, nothing worked." "You'll have to pay her. Buy it back." "She won't sell." "Then we'll have to steal it." "We tried that five times already! My guys broke into her house twice. Once we stole her luggage when she was traveling. And she was ambushed twice. Nothing!" "Didn't find a single clue?" "Nothing." Holmes chuckled. "This is quite a little problem, isn't it?" "It's a huge problem for me," the King said. "You're right, it is. So what's she going to do with this photo?" "Ruin me." "But how?" "I'm about to get married." "So I've heard." "To Clotilde Lothman von Saxe-Meiningen, the Scandinavian King's second daughter. You must know her family is very strict. And she's the picture of innocence. Even the tiniest whiff of scandal would end things instantly." "And Irene Adler?" "She's going to send them that photo, I know she will. You don't know her, she's got a will of iron. Most beautiful woman you've ever seen, but with the mind of a ruthless criminal. She'll do anything to stop me from marrying this other woman, anything." "You're certain she hasn't sent the photo yet?" "Positive." "Why are you so sure?" "Because she told me she would send it the day the engagement is announced. This Monday." "Well, good thing we have three days then," Holmes said, yawning. "I've got a couple of loose ends to tie up at the moment. Your Majesty will be staying in London for the time being, I presume?" "Of course, of course. You can reach me at the Langham Hotel, under the name Count Von Kramm." "I'll let you know how things are going." "Please do, I'm on pins and needles over here." "Now, about payment‚Ä¶" "Don't worry about it, the sky's the limit." "Seriously?" "I'd give you one of my provinces for that photo, I'm not kidding." "And for expenses?" The King took out a fat leather bag and tossed it on the table. "Three hundred in gold, seven hundred in cash," he said. Holmes scribbled him a receipt. "And the lady's address?" "Briony Lodge, on Serpentine Avenue in St. John's Wood." Holmes wrote it down. "Just one more thing: was the photo a cabinet card?" "Yes, it was." "Right then, good night, Your Majesty. I think we'll have good news for you soon. And good night to you too, Watson," he said as we heard the royal carriage pulling away. "Come by tomorrow afternoon around three, we'll talk about this whole thing."

scenes.scene_summary: The narrator returns to Baker Street the next day. Holmes arrives late, disguised as a groom, and recounts his investigation of Irene Adler's house and her relationship with Godfrey Norton.
scenes.text_segment: At three o'clock sharp, I was back on Baker Street. No sign of Holmes. His landlady said he'd left early that morning. So I sat by the fire, waiting. I have to admit, this case had really piqued my interest. Even though it wasn't a murder or anything, something about the mystery of the missing photo, and who this Irene Adler really was, not to mention having a king as a client, made it all very intriguing. Plus, it was fascinating to watch Holmes work; he was so incredibly sharp and observant. I was so used to him being right that I never even considered the possibility of him failing. It was almost four when he finally showed up, looking like he'd been on a bender! He had on these shabby clothes, his face was red and kind of swollen, and he had these ridiculous sideburns. I knew Holmes was a master of disguise, but I swear, I had to look three times before I was sure it was really him! He gave me a quick nod and disappeared into his bedroom. Five minutes later, he came out, back to his normal self, wearing his usual tweed suit. He shoved his hands in his pockets, stretched out his legs in front of the fire, and burst out laughing. "You are not going to believe this!" he said, but then he started choking and laughing so hard he could barely breathe. "What? What is it?" I asked. "It's just‚Ä¶ too perfect. You'll never guess what I've been up to all day!" "I can't even imagine. I'm assuming you went to check out Miss Adler's place and see what she's like?" "Bingo. But you won't believe what happened! I left here around eight this morning, dressed as a groom who was out of work. Guys who like horses always stick together, did you know that? Easy to blend in, and you learn all sorts of things. Found Briony Lodge easy enough. Small, but nice, with a garden in the back, right on the street. Two floors. Basic lock on the door. Big living room on the right with those huge windows - easy to open, even a kid could do it. Nothing much in the back, except that you could reach the passage window from the roof of the coach house. I walked around the whole place, checked it out good, but didn't see anything else important. "So I headed down to the end of the street where I figured there'd be stables, and I was right. I helped the stable boys groom the horses and got a couple pennies, some watered-down beer, a few cigarettes, and more information than I could ever want about our Miss Adler - not to mention all the gossip about half the neighborhood! Not that I cared about them, but I had to pretend to be interested." "And what about Irene Adler? What did you learn?" "Let's just say all the guys were head over heels for her, she's quite a looker, apparently. The prettiest woman any of them had ever seen. That's what they all said at the stables, anyway. Quiet life: sings at concerts, goes for a drive at five, home for dinner at seven sharp. Doesn't go out much other than for her concerts. Has this one guy who visits her a lot - a good-looking fella with dark hair. Comes at least once a day, sometimes twice. Name's Godfrey Norton, lawyer. See, being a cabby, you learn all sorts of juicy gossip. They'd driven him home often enough to know everything about him. So after getting all the dirt, I strolled past Briony Lodge again, planning my next move. "This Godfrey Norton guy, he's a big part of this, I can tell. Lawyer, that's never good. Had to figure out what their deal was. Is she his client? Friend? Or something more? Client, maybe she gave him the photo. If they were involved, less likely. That was the question, and the answer would determine if I should focus on her place or his. Tricky situation. Sorry to bore you with all this, but if you're going to write all this down, I have to give you the details, right?" "Don't worry, I'm following," I told him. He continued, "I was still trying to figure out what to do when a cab pulled up, and this guy jumped out. He fit the description perfectly: handsome, dark, mustache. Clearly the Norton fellow. And in a hurry, too. Yelled at the cabby to wait, practically pushed past the maid. "He was inside maybe half an hour, pacing back and forth, talking with his hands, totally worked up. I couldn't get a look at her. Then he came out, even more flustered than before. Checked his watch and yelled at the cabby, 'Get me to Gross & Hankey's on Regent Street, then St. Monica's Church on Edgeware Road - and make it snappy, twenty minutes! You'll get an extra shilling!' Off they went, and I was trying to decide if I should follow them, when a fancy little carriage came up. Coachman looked a mess, but the woman who came rushing out of the house and into the carriage, she was beautiful! Stunning! "St. Monica's, John!" she called out to the driver. "And there's a half-sovereign in it for you if you get me there in twenty minutes!" "Watson, I couldn't resist. This was too good! I was about to chase after them, when an empty cab came by. The driver didn't look too happy to see me, but I got in before he could say anything. 'St. Monica's! And step on it, twenty minutes! There's a reward in it for you!' It was a quarter after eleven, and I knew exactly what was about to happen. "The cabby got us there fast! I swear, I've never gone that fast in my life. But the other two, they were already there! Their horses were steaming; they must've really pushed them. I paid the cabby and raced inside. There was no one there except for the lovebirds, a priest, and an empty church. They were huddled together by the altar, and the priest looked like he was arguing with them. I pretended to be some lost soul who wandered in and walked casually down the aisle. Suddenly, they all turned and looked at me, and Godfrey Norton came running towards me as fast as he could. "Thank God!" he said. "You'll do. Come on, come on!" "What? What's going on?" I asked. "No time to explain, man, every second counts! Three minutes, or it won't be legal!" "Next thing I know, they've practically dragged me up to the altar, whispering stuff in my ear, and I'm repeating it! Vouching for all these things I know nothing about! Turns out, they needed a witness to make it legal, and there I was, at the right place at the right time! Saved the day! The bride gave me a sovereign; I'm going to have to get myself a pocket watch to wear it on. What a day!" And that's when he'd started laughing so hard. "Well, that's a twist," I said. "What happened next?" "My carefully laid plans were down the drain, that's what! Looked like they were about to take off, so I had to think fast. But then, at the church door, they took off in different directions: he went back to the Temple, she went home. I heard her say to him, 'See you in the park at five, like always.' And that was that. Time to figure something else out." "And‚Ä¶ what exactly are we going to do?" "Let's eat first, then I'll explain everything. It's almost five now, we need to be ready in two hours. Miss Irene - or Mrs. Norton, I guess - will be home from her drive around seven. We'll be waiting for her." "And then what?" "Just leave that part to me. I've got it all planned out. There's just one thing. You can't interfere, no matter what. You got it?" "I'm just supposed to blend in?" "Exactly. You might see some things you don't like, but stay out of it. Eventually, they'll bring me inside the house. Just wait five minutes, and the living room window will open. You need to be right there, by that window." "Got it." "Keep your eyes on me, you'll be able to see me." "Okay." "And when I raise my hand like this‚Ä¶ you throw this into the room and yell 'Fire!' Got it? Don't worry, it's nothing dangerous." He pulled something out of his pocket that looked like a big cigar. "It's a smoke flare, plumbers use them. Lights on both ends. That's your job, simple as that. Once you yell 'Fire!', other people will hear and join in. Then you head down to the end of the street, and I'll meet you in ten minutes. You got all that?" "Let's see‚Ä¶ I do nothing, I go to the window, I watch for your signal, I throw that thing inside, yell 'Fire!', and wait for you at the corner." "Perfect. I knew I could count on you." "So, what exactly is the plan?" "All in good time. It's almost time for me to get into character anyway." He went back to his room and came back a few minutes later dressed like a really nice, but maybe not too bright, priest. He had on a big black hat, baggy pants, one of those white ties priests wear, and he had this kind of goofy smile that would make you trust him instantly. It was more than just the clothes; his whole demeanor changed. You'd think he was a completely different person! What a shame he became a detective. He would've been an amazing actor.

shots.text_segment: I left here around eight this morning, dressed as a groom who was out of work. Guys who like horses always stick together, did you know that? Easy to blend in, and you learn all sorts of things. Found Briony Lodge easy enough. Small, but nice, with a garden in the back, right on the street. Two floors. Basic lock on the door. Big living room on the right with those huge windows - easy to open, even a kid could do it. Nothing much in the back, except that you could reach the passage window from the roof of the coach house. I walked around the whole place, checked it out good, but didn't see anything else important.

scenes.scene_summary: Holmes and Watson go to Serpentine Avenue to execute their plan. They observe the street and wait for Irene Adler's return. Holmes describes his strategy to retrieve the photograph.
scenes.text_segment: It was a quarter past six when we left Baker Street, and about ten to seven when we got to Serpentine Avenue. The sun was setting, streetlights were starting to come on, and we were hanging out in front of Briony Lodge, waiting. It looked exactly like Holmes described, but there were more people around than I expected. For a small street, it was pretty lively. A bunch of guys were smoking and laughing on the corner, there was a guy sharpening knives with one of those wheels, a couple of soldiers were flirting with a nanny, and some upper-class guys were strutting around smoking cigars. "See," said Holmes, "the marriage actually makes things simpler. The photo's a problem for both of them now. She doesn't want her new hubby to see it any more than our friend wants his fianc√©e to see it. Question is, where is it?" "Good question." "No way she's carrying it around with her. It's too big. She knows the King's men might try to mug her ‚Äì which they already did twice, remember? So yeah, it's not on her." "Then where is it?" "Maybe her bank? Or a lawyer's office? Those are possibilities, but my gut says no. Women like their secrets, and they like to keep them close. Why trust someone else? Plus, she's planning on using it soon. Has to be somewhere she can grab it quickly. It's in her house." "But it's been robbed twice already." "Those guys were amateurs, they wouldn't know a clue if it hit 'em in the face." "And you do?" "I'm not going to look for it." "You're not? Then how‚Ä¶?" "I'll get her to show me, it's foolproof." "She'll never go for it." "She won't have a choice. Wait, I hear wheels. It's her." Just as he said it, we saw the lights of a carriage. A fancy little thing pulled up. One of the guys from the corner ran up to open the door, hoping for a tip, but one of the other guys shoved him out of the way. They got into a huge yelling match, then the soldiers got involved, and the knife-sharpener jumped in too, waving his tools around. Punches flew, and suddenly this woman, who'd gotten out of the carriage, was right in the middle of this brawl! Holmes jumped into the chaos to protect her, but as soon as he reached her, he cried out and fell to the ground, blood all over his face. The soldiers and the other guys disappeared, and a bunch of well-dressed people who'd been watching the fight suddenly rushed forward to help the woman and check on the "injured" man. Irene Adler, as I still thought of her, ran up the steps to her front door but turned to look back at the commotion. "Is the poor man badly hurt?" she asked. "He's dead!" shouted some. "No, he's alive!" shouted others. "But he won't make it to the hospital in time." "He's a brave man," said one woman. "Those thugs were after her purse and her jewels! They'd have gotten away with it if he hadn't stepped in. Oh look, he's breathing again!" "We can't just leave him here in the street! Can we bring him inside, miss?" "Of course, of course! Bring him into the sitting room, there's a comfortable sofa in there. This way, quickly!" They carefully carried him into the house. I was watching from my post by the window. They'd turned on the lights inside, but the curtains weren't drawn. I could see them laying Holmes down on the sofa. Part of me thought he looked guilty about tricking everyone, but honestly, I was the one.

shots.visual_description: The scene opens at dusk in Serpentine Avenue. The sun is setting, casting long shadows across the street as streetlights begin to flicker on. Holmes and Watson are visible in the foreground, standing inconspicuously near Briony Lodge. The street is bustling with activity despite its small size. On the corner, a group of working-class men in rough clothing are gathered, smoking and laughing boisterously. Nearby, a man in a leather apron operates a knife-sharpening wheel, the sparks flying as he works. Two soldiers in crisp uniforms are flirting with a young woman in a nanny's uniform, while well-dressed gentlemen in top hats and tails stroll by, puffing on cigars. The atmosphere is lively and slightly chaotic, with a mix of social classes intermingling on the street.
shots.text_segment: It was a quarter past six when we left Baker Street, and about ten to seven when we got to Serpentine Avenue. The sun was setting, streetlights were starting to come on, and we were hanging out in front of Briony Lodge, waiting. It looked exactly like Holmes described, but there were more people around than I expected. For a small street, it was pretty lively. A bunch of guys were smoking and laughing on the corner, there was a guy sharpening knives with one of those wheels, a couple of soldiers were flirting with a nanny, and some upper-class guys were strutting around smoking cigars.
