shots.visual_description: The shot focuses on Holmes and Watson, standing close together near the edge of the street. Holmes, tall and lean with sharp features, is dressed in his characteristic deerstalker cap and long coat. He speaks animatedly, his eyes bright with excitement as he explains his deductions to Watson. Watson, shorter and stockier with a thick mustache, listens intently, his brow furrowed in concentration. Behind them, Briony Lodge looms, a grand Victorian house with ornate windows and a well-manicured front garden. The street continues to bustle around them, but they remain focused on their conversation, oblivious to the activity.
shots.text_segment: "See," said Holmes, "the marriage actually makes things simpler. The photo's a problem for both of them now. She doesn't want her new hubby to see it any more than our friend wants his fianc√©e to see it. Question is, where is it?" "Good question." "No way she's carrying it around with her. It's too big. She knows the King's men might try to mug her ‚Äì which they already did twice, remember? So yeah, it's not on her." "Then where is it?" "Maybe her bank? Or a lawyer's office? Those are possibilities, but my gut says no. Women like their secrets, and they like to keep them close. Why trust someone else? Plus, she's planning on using it soon. Has to be somewhere she can grab it quickly. It's in her house." "But it's been robbed twice already." "Those guys were amateurs, they wouldn't know a clue if it hit 'em in the face." "And you do?" "I'm not going to look for it." "You're not? Then how‚Ä¶?" "I'll get her to show me, it's foolproof." "She'll never go for it." "She won't have a choice. Wait, I hear wheels. It's her."

shots.visual_description: The street suddenly comes alive with new energy as a luxurious carriage pulls up in front of Briony Lodge. The carriage is ornate, with gleaming wood and brass fittings, pulled by two well-groomed horses. As it comes to a stop, several men from the corner group rush towards it, jostling each other to be the first to open the door. One man, dressed in shabby clothes, reaches for the handle, but another, slightly better dressed, shoves him aside roughly. This sparks an immediate and violent reaction. The two men begin shouting, their faces red with anger, fists clenched. The commotion draws in the nearby soldiers, who move to intervene, and the knife-sharpener, who approaches wielding his tools menacingly. The scene descends into chaos as punches start flying, creating a swirling mass of fighting men right in front of the carriage.
shots.text_segment: Just as he said it, we saw the lights of a carriage. A fancy little thing pulled up. One of the guys from the corner ran up to open the door, hoping for a tip, but one of the other guys shoved him out of the way. They got into a huge yelling match, then the soldiers got involved, and the knife-sharpener jumped in too, waving his tools around. Punches flew, and suddenly this woman, who'd gotten out of the carriage, was right in the middle of this brawl!

shots.visual_description: In the midst of the chaotic brawl, a woman emerges from the carriage. She is strikingly beautiful, dressed in an elegant evening gown with sparkling jewelry. Her face shows a mix of shock and fear as she finds herself surrounded by the fighting men. Suddenly, Holmes springs into action, pushing his way through the crowd towards her. His face is set with determination as he reaches out to protect her. Just as he gets to her side, Holmes lets out a convincing cry of pain and collapses to the ground. Blood (likely fake, but convincing to onlookers) covers his face as he lies motionless on the cobblestones. The fighting men, seeing this turn of events, quickly disperse and vanish into the night. The well-dressed bystanders who had been watching the fight now rush forward, their faces a mix of concern and curiosity. They gather around Holmes and the woman, creating a circle of worried onlookers.
shots.text_segment: Holmes jumped into the chaos to protect her, but as soon as he reached her, he cried out and fell to the ground, blood all over his face. The soldiers and the other guys disappeared, and a bunch of well-dressed people who'd been watching the fight suddenly rushed forward to help the woman and check on the "injured" man. Irene Adler, as I still thought of her, ran up the steps to her front door but turned to look back at the commotion. "Is the poor man badly hurt?" she asked. "He's dead!" shouted some. "No, he's alive!" shouted others. "But he won't make it to the hospital in time." "He's a brave man," said one woman. "Those thugs were after her purse and her jewels! They'd have gotten away with it if he hadn't stepped in. Oh look, he's breathing again!" "We can't just leave him here in the street! Can we bring him inside, miss?"

shots.text_segment: "Of course, of course! Bring him into the sitting room, there's a comfortable sofa in there. This way, quickly!" They carefully carried him into the house. I was watching from my post by the window. They'd turned on the lights inside, but the curtains weren't drawn. I could see them laying Holmes down on the sofa. Part of me thought he looked guilty about tricking everyone, but honestly, I was the one.
